Privacy Hero 2 - Adapter <-> Backend Websocket API 0.1.5

The API for Adapter to Backend communication.

Overview

All communication is carried out through a single websocket connection per adapter. The Adapter connects and sends updates to state or requests for configuration as required, and is also triggered to perform operations or update its state asynchronously from the backend through the same connection.

Both directions of the connection use the same basic message format.

Operations

The API is broken down by operation, and message type/source.

Documentation Conventions:

  • SUB [Subscribe] messages are messages which are sent to the Backend from the Adapter.
  • PUB [Publish] messages are messages which are sent to the Adapter from the Backend.

The API does not have any inherent Publish/Subscribe semantics. This is a documentation convention only.

All messages to/from the adapter have a common format, which are documented in the Basic Message Forms. set of operations.

CHANGELOG

V0.1.5

  1. Added Block List Cfg message.
  2. Added Block List Applied message.
  3. Referenced blocklist config messages from Link Established.
  4. Added all current config messages needed to be sent on startup to Link Established.

V0.1.4

  1. Broke down the messages into smaller groups to ease document navigation.
  2. Added WIFI Configuration message.
  3. Added Streaming Auth message.

V0.1.3

  1. Fix Example for Device Information
  2. Better document how the speed and latency are calculated in VPN Server Connect
  3. Better explain that VPN Server Connect message with an empty list of servers is to be used as a vpn_disconnect message.

V0.1.2

  1. Modified speedtest result message Speedtest Result to track pperf implementation on router.
  2. Changed organization of VPN server configuration in VPN Server Connect.
  3. VPN Connection Status updated to track new server id field.

V0.1.1

  1. Added the Adapter Reset Reset Router message.
  2. Added the Adapter Resetting Router Reseting reply.

V0.1.0

  1. Added hyperlinks between messages to ease navigation.
  2. Added WPS service enable to Adapter Services message (and reply Adapter Service State).
  3. Added Subscribed service enable to Adapter Services message (and reply Adapter Service State).
  4. Removed "VPN" from Adapter Services (and reply Adapter Service State).
  5. Added VPN Server Connect message.
  6. Added VPN Server Reconnect message.
  7. Added VPN Connection Status message.
  8. Made ID field optional but present in every message by including in the Base Message specification.
  9. Created Unsubscribed Whitelist message to set configuration whitelist of domains which are still accessible when the router subscription is invalid.
  10. Add list of config messages sent by backend as a result of initial connection.
  11. Add the WPS Status message.

Servers

ws2-dev.privacyhero.com wss

Development server

Security:
  • User / Password:

    The user password follows the form <Adapter MAC>:<Adapter Secret Hash>

    • Adapter MAC is the hardware Mac address of the Adapter and it must be the same as the mac used to register the adapter in production. The MAC has the format 00:11:22:33:44:55 or 001122334455 or 00-11-22-33-44-55 all of which are equivalent
    • Adapter Secret Hash is a Base64-URL encoded SHA256 hash of the unique id contained within the cpu or chips of the adapter.

    An example user:password is (the binary secret is the string password ):

    00:11:22:33:44:55:XohImNooBHFR0OVvjcYpJ3NgPQ1qq73WKhHvch0VQtg

    The user/password is passed in the Authorization header of the http connection which established the websocket.

    • Adapter Secret Hash is a Base64-URL encoded SHA256 hash of the unique id contained within the cpu or chips of the adapter.

Operations

Pub COMMON

The common channel is not an actual channel. It defines the basic message structure upon which all other messages are based.

Basic Message Forms

All messages are sent by each end of the websocket as required. These message formats are equally valid for transmission from the adapter [SUB] as well as transmission by the back end [PUB].

There is no strict Subscribe/Publish semantic it is documentation convention ONLY. The websocket acts as two unidirectional message pipes and Sub/Pub messages are formatted, sent, received and treated identically and without distinction.

Accepts one of the following messages:

#1 Base Message BaseMsg

Standard Message Base Format

Message Formats

All Privacy Hero 2 system messages have the following standard form.

Payload
object
message
required
string

This is the name of the message. The operation that is to be performed and the further fields contained within the message can be identified based solely on this message type string.

tstamp
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

Every adapter/backend generated message contains a unique tstamp field. This field defines both the time of a particular event having ocurred, and the pairing of messages in the case of events which are triggered as a result of commands from the backend.

An Adapter will always return the tstamp of any message it is replying to. IF the Adapter is generating an event asynchronously and not as a result of a direct comment, the tstamp contains the time of the event as generated by the adapter.

The Field is an integer and is the number of milliseconds since midnight 1970, UTC. Otherwise known as the Unix Epoch.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. This field is only sent if this message is a reply to a message received from the backend, AND that message included the ID Field. In that case, it is included unchanged.

Additional properties are allowed.

#2 Multi Message MultiMsg

Multiple Message Packet

Message Formats

All Privacy Hero 2 system messages may be bundled into a single multi-message. The multi message is a standard message, which hold an array of individual messages. The individual messages when received will be treated as if they were received sequentially and independently in the order they are listed.

The purpose of a Multi-Message is to cluster message processing for efficiency.

Notes regarding adapter bundling implementation.

The Backend is charged in 100ms units of execution. It also takes time for the backend to startup and begin processing. Therefore, it is preferable, unless the message is urgent, that all messages are bundled in the adapter in a minimum of 200ms blocks. If an urgent message must be sent, it should be added to the current bundle and the entire bundle be sent immediately.

The maximum single multi-message size must not exceed 32KB. If adding a message to the bundle would cause the message size to exceed 32KB, the bundle should be sent and the message which would have exceeded the size is added to the next bundle. IF a message is defined which does exceed 32KB, it should not be bundled, but MUST be sent as a discreet message. In this case, the maximum message size must never exceed 128KB.

The multi-message is guaranteed NOT to have an id field, but the messages contained within it, may have id fields and they should be processed accordingly.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 5 length >= 5

Multiple Message Packet.

Const: "multi"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the message was generated, unrelated to the bundled messages timestamps.

msgs
required
array<object>
>= 1 items <= 32 items

An array of complete and individual messages as defined elsewhere in this specification.

Items:

0
object
message
required
string

This is the name of the message. The operation that is to be performed and the further fields contained within the message can be identified based solely on this message type string.

tstamp
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

Every adapter/backend generated message contains a unique tstamp field. This field defines both the time of a particular event having ocurred, and the pairing of messages in the case of events which are triggered as a result of commands from the backend.

An Adapter will always return the tstamp of any message it is replying to. IF the Adapter is generating an event asynchronously and not as a result of a direct comment, the tstamp contains the time of the event as generated by the adapter.

The Field is an integer and is the number of milliseconds since midnight 1970, UTC. Otherwise known as the Unix Epoch.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

Additional properties are allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Message Formats

Examples

BaseMsg
Payload 
{
  "message": "example",
  "tstamp": 1592217870123,
  "id": "eyJ0aGlzIjoiaXMiLCJhbiI6ImV4YW1wbGUiLCJpZCI6ZmllbGQifQ"
}

  "message": "multi",
  "tstamp": 1592217870123,
  "msgs": []
}

Pub AWS_ERRORS

These are AWS Generated error messages from the backend to the adapter.

They are generated by the AWS infrastructure, and not the backend code.

IF the adapter receives one, it should assume the link is fatally compromised and internally record the error. It should then drop the websocket connection and attempt to reconnect to the backed. After a successful reconnection, the error should be logged to the AWS backend.

AWS Error Messages

AWS Error Message from the Backend to the Adapter.

Accepts one of the following messages:

#1 AWS Internal Server Error AWSInternalServerError

AWS Internal Server Error

AWS Errors

This message is generated directly by AWS, and does not contain a tstamp.

This messages indicates something fatal has ocurred in the server. Upon receipt, the adapter should record the fact it ocurred, and try and reconnect to the backend, if a successful reconnection occurs, the adapter should log the internal server error to the backend, and then continue.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 21 length >= 21

An internal server error, AWS Generated

Const: "Internal server error"
connectionId
required
string

The AWS Websocket Connection ID.

requestId
required
string

The ID of the request which caused the error.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

#2 AWS Server Error AWSServerError

AWS Server Error

AWS Errors

This message is generated directly by AWS, and does not contain a tstamp.

This messages indicates something fatal has ocurred in the server. Upon receipt, the adapter should record the fact it ocurred, and try and reconnect to the backend, if a successful reconnection occurs, the adapter should log the internal server error to the backend, and then continue.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 5 length >= 5

A general server error, AWS Generated

Const: "Error"
error
required
string

The description of the Error.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

AWS Errors

Examples

AWSInternalServerError
Payload 
{
  "message": "Internal server error",
  "connectionId": "d2Vic29ja2V0IElE",
  "requestId": "cmVxdWVzdCBJRA"
}

  "error": "An error ocurred."
}
This example has been generated automatically.

Pub CONNECTION

These are messages related to the websocket connection and its management.

NOTES

  1. AWS will terminate a websocket after remaining idle for 10 minutes.
  2. AWS May terminate a websocket connection that has been continuously made for 2 Hours.

There is nothing preventing the link being immediately re-established.

TODO:

It is not clear if websocket pings are sufficient to avoid the 10 minute idle timeout. This needs to be tested.

If it is not sufficient, we will need to do periodic heartbeats at around 9 minute intervals to prevent the idle timeout.

It seems there is nothing we can do about the 2 hour timeout except reconnect. This timeout needs to be tested.

Adapter Link Management

Initial Configuration.

Accepts one of the following messages:

#1 Initial Configuration InitialConfig

Initial Highest Level Configuration

Adapter Messages

This message contains the highest level configuration and is sent by the backend after a link is established, and the backend receives the Link Established message from the Adapter.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 11 length >= 11

Initial Highest Level Configuration

Const: "initial cfg"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The tstamp in this message is the same tstamp sent in the Link Established message from the adapter which triggered it to be sent.

version
required
string
bas64-url-sha256 length <= 43 length >= 43

The version of the latest firmaware suitable for the adapter. This version should match the version installed in the adapter before it continues. If it does noe, the adapter should retrieve the new version from the url in this message, program that and restart the connection.

firmware
required
string
url

The firmware url. This is the location where the latest firmware may be downloaded. If the adapter detects that a firmware update is required it downloads the firmware from this URL. If the firmware can not be downloaded or the image downloaded does not match the version hash, then the firmware in the adapter must not be changed, and an error should be logged to the backend.

loglevel
required
string

The Minimum level of messages which should be logged to the backend.

Enum: "NONE" "ERROR" "WARNING" "DEBUG"

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

#2 Router Reset Reset

Cause Router to do a hardware reset.

Adapter Messages

This message causes, after an optional delay, the router to be reset. Router Reseting is sent in reply to this message before the reset occurs.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 5 length >= 5

Cause Router to do a hardware reset.

Const: "reset"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The tstamp in this message is set by the Backend and must be returned verbatim in the reply.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

in
integer
int64

The number of seconds to delay before resetting. IF omitted, reset as fast as possible.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

#3 Unsubscribed Whitelist UnsubscribedWhitelist

List of all urls that may be accessed when the router is not subscribed.

Adapter Messages

This message contains the list of urls devices may access when there is no active subscription for the router. It is sent in response to a Link Established message from the Adapter.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 22 length >= 22

List of all urls that may be accessed when the router is not subscribed.

Const: "unsubscribed-whitelist"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The tstamp in this message is the same tstamp sent in the Link Established message from the adapter which triggered it to be sent.

whitelist
required
array<string>
>= 1 items

A list of regex url domains which, if matched, are allowed to be accessed even when the router is unsubscribed. All other HTTP traffic is routed to a url specified in the proxy field.

I addition, all HTTPS traffic not to a whitelisted domain is simply blocked.

This functionality is ONLY active if the Adapter Services "Subscribed" service state is False.

Items:

0
string
regex

A URL Regex to match.

Additional items are allowed.

proxy
string
url

The URL to route all non-whitelisted traffic to.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Payload 
{
  "message": "initial cfg",
  "tstamp": 1592217870123,
  "version": "uDHqOfzVFgcldv41fTTAOVtJSLVxn8M36ufxrEnWtzg",
  "firmware": "https://dl.privacyhero.com/firmware/adapter_v107.fw",
  "loglevel": "DEBUG"
}

  "tstamp": 1592217870123,

    "^(.*\\.)?privacyhero.com$",
    "^.*\\.chargebee.com$"
  ]
}

Adapter Link Management

Link Management Messages from the Adapter.

Accepts one of the following messages:

#1 Link Established LinkEstablished

Advise the Backend that the Adapter has connected to a new websocket

Adapter Messages

This message is sent from the Adapter to the Backend as the very first message it sends AFTER establishing any websocket connection to the backend. It allows the backend to perform link connection housekeeping for the adapter, which is necessary for proper operation.

Upon receipt, the Backend will queue the initial configuration for the router in the following order:

  1. Initial Configuration
  2. Unsubscribed Whitelist
  3. Block List Cfg (1 message for each blocklist category)
  4. Adapter Services
  5. WIFI Configuration
  6. VPN Server Connect
  7. Streaming Auth
  8. Streaming Cfg
  9. Known Devices
  10. Change Device State (As many as required to configure all devices)
  11. Set Bedtime (1 message each for as many bedtime schedules exist.)
Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 16 length >= 16

Advise the Backend that the Adapter has connected to a new websocket

Const: "link established"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the link established message was queued by the Adapter. (According to the adapters internal clock.)

version
required
string
bas64-url-sha256 length <= 43 length >= 43

sha256 hash of the firmware image currently loaded in the Adapter. Encoded with base64-url encoding.

variant
string
length >= 1

Optional: Identifier to specify what type of operation the adapter is performing. This is used to allow the system to deploy different software versions to the same hardware. Normally the backend will not change the variant but will advise about the latest version of software for that variant.

disconnected
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

Optional: If this message is being sent because the link was disconnected, the disconnected field is sent, containing the time in milliseconds when the adapter detected the link had failed. If this is the first connection since power on, this field is omitted.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

#2 Router Resetting Resetting

Router is going to do a hardware reset.

Adapter Messages

This message is sent as a reply to the Reset Router message.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 9 length >= 9

Router is going to do a hardware reset.

Const: "resetting"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The tstamp in this message is the same tstamp sent in the Link Established message from the adapter which triggered it to be sent.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. This field is only sent if this message is a reply to a message received from the backend, AND that message included the ID Field. In that case, it is included unchanged.

in
integer
int64

The number of seconds before the reset will occur. IF omitted, reset is imminent.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

  "variant": "PHero2-Router",
  "disconnected": 1592316782123
}

Pub CONFIGURATION

These are messages related to the configuration of the adapter.

These messages are sent on initial connection and also periodically as required to reflect user changes in the configuration.

Adapter Configuration

Commands to set the Adapter Configuration.

Accepts the following message:

Adapter Services AdapterServices

Configure Adapter Level services on the Adapter.

Adapter Messages

This message causes the adapter that receives it to turn on/off the adapter wide services specified. If any service is not specified, its state is not changed.

IF the message contains multiple states, they may be replied to either individually or as a group. In particular, "VPN" may take a long time to start. "VPN" will not be replied to until the "VPN" has fully started or has failed.

See the "vpn_status_update" message which allows progressive and detailed vpn startup/shutdown state to be reported to the Backend asynchronously.

Regardless of the requested state, the reply for "VPN" always reflects the state which was achieved. ie, if the VPN state in teh request was true, but the VPN failed to start, the reply must specify the actual state as false. If other states may also fail to configure, they too must be replied with their actual state, and not the requested state.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 16 length >= 16

Configure Adapter Level services on the Adapter.

Const: "adapter-services"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The request timestamp of the configuration, this tstamp must be returned in the reply with the results as the message tstamp. In the

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

services

Sub CONFIGURATION

These are messages related to the configuration of the adapter.

These messages are sent on initial connection and also periodically as required to reflect user changes in the configuration.

Adapter Configuration

Configuration Acknowledgements from the Adapter

Accepts the following message:

Adapter Services State AdapterServicesState

Report current state of a service on the Adapter.

Adapter Messages

This is the reply to setting the adapter service states from the Adapter Services message.

If the configuration command contained multiple services, the reply may also contain multiple services, or services may be responded to in a group or individual, depending on how long the service takes to start on the adapter and the adapters implementation. However, each reply must contain the tstamp from the original command from the backend, and the ID if present.

This reply informs the backend of the final state of the service, ie, if UPNP server was commanded to turn on, but fails, the reply will be sent as a result of the failure AND will have its state set to false. The tstamp will still reflect the tstamp in the original command, as will the ID if present.

VPN status updates are not reported using this message. See the VPN Connection Status message for details.

IF a service state can change without command from the backend, this message is sent unsolicited with the changed state for the service. in that case, the tstamp MUST be set to the tstamp of the time the state changed on the adapter, and there must be no ID field.

Pub VPN_CONFIGURATION

These are messages related to the configuration of the VPN in the adapter.

These messages are sent on initial connection and also periodically as required to reflect user changes in the configuration.

Adapter VPN Configuration

VPN Commands to set the Adapter Configuration.

Accepts the following message:

VPN Server Connect VPNConnect

Connect to a listed VPN Server.

Adapter Messages

This message causes the router to attempt to connect to one of the listed VPN servers.

If there are untested servers in the list (servers without either the "speed" or "latency" fields in their configuration), the router will test them, and send the result back to the backend. After testing is completed, the router will sort them, in order of fatest/lowest latency and then attempt to connect in that order.

If there are no servers to be tested, then they are attempted to be connected in the order presented.

IF the router has already established a VPN connection, AND the VPN server connected is present in the list (regardless of whether it has test data or not), then no reconnection will occur and it will not disconnect or attempt to reconnect as a result of receiving this message. It will simply reply with the VPN Connection Status Message indicating the current server is connected.

However, if the current VPN server connected IS NOT in the list, then the connection will be dropped and the list will be processed as if there was no connection to begin with.

IF the server list is empty, and the VPN is connected, the Router will immediately drop the connection and report the connection is down using the VPN Connection Status message.

This message is sent when a client requests the VPN connection be established, OR the Router has requested a VPN Server Reconnect.

Because the router can ONLY rely on the credentials it was presented at the time the vpn-connect message was received, if for any reason the VPN tunnel disconnects, the router can try to immediately reconnect to the same tunnel with the same credentials. If that fails, it can not use the credentials presented for any other tunnel as they may have expired or have been assigned to a different client. In that case, the router can send a VPN Server Reconnect message to the backend to be provided with a fresh list of VPN servers and credentials with wish to re-establish VPN connection. The backend will then reply with this VPN Server Connect message.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 11 length >= 11

Connect to a listed VPN Server.

Const: "vpn-connect"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The request timestamp of the configuration.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

servers
required
array<object>
>= 1 items

The message will contain a list of viable pre-selected servers.

The highest priority entires (and therefore the first listed) will be those servers which require testing, in order of test priority. There may be no servers of this type listed if there are no servers that REQUIRE testing.

Following this will be a list of servers in priority order. When connecting to the VPN, the router is to use this list and try to connect in the order presented. IF the router is unable to establish a connection after trying all servers, it gives up attempting to connect.

Items:

0
object

The configuration for an individual VPN server.

The vpn_id is to be used to report about status and speedtest results for the configured vpn tunnel.

speed is the average speedtest TX result from the last months worth vpn speedtests on this server. IF there is no speed field, the router is to create the speed value by connecting the tunnel and performing the speedtest. The resulting TX speed in bytes per second of this one test becomes the speed for the purpose of selecting the fastest VPN Server. Speed is selected as the TX value because most consumer internet connections are asynchronous, but have higher raw TX speed than RX, that means that any speedtest is more likely to max out RX than TX.

latency is the average latency to the speedtest server from the last months worth of speedtest results on the server. IF there is a missing latency result (ie, the speedtest reported -1) then the latency value for the purpose of averaging is taken to be 1000ms which will force the latency to dis-favor links with unreliable connections. The average is rounded to the nearest whole millisecond.

speed and latency will either both be present, or neither present. If neither is present, the VPN tunnel is to be started and tested.

The array will be pre-sorted in order from backend identified fastest server to slowest. However, when the router must perform a speedtest to determine the vpn speed, it must resort. The sorting algorithm works like this:

Place all servers in an unsorted list of servers.
Create a sorted list of servers which initally is empty.

Of the servers in the list of unsorted servers, get the maximum speed
value.
Of the servers in the unsorted list whose speed is within 10% of the
fastest speed in the list, remove the server with the lowest latency value
and add it to the end of the list of sorted vpn servers.
Repeat this selection process until there are no more servers in the
unsorted server list.

This algorithm will create a list of servers which trend from fastest/lowest latency down to slowest/highest latency.

vpn_id
required
string

Unique VPN ID

speed
integer
int64

Current rated bandwidth for the tunnel in bytes per second.

latency
integer
int64

Current rated latency for the tunnel in milliseconds.

config
oneOf

#2 VPN Connection Status VPNStatus

Adapter Messages

required

The current status of the VPN process.

  • test-connecting = Connecting to a VPN server to test.
  • testing = Test connection to VPN succeeded and test started. Test results will be sent in Speedtest Result.
  • test-failed = Either the connection couldn't be established to test, or the test has failed to execute.
  • connecting = Connecting the VPN tunnel for general use.
  • connected = The connection to the VPN is established and routing is operational.
  • failed = The vpn server failed to connect or the link broke. After this call the router may no longer use the credentials presented in VPN Server Connect for the server.

  • disconnected = The last possible server was tested and failed, giving up trying to enable VPN. server should not be present, as no server is being accessed in this state.

Pub WIFI_CONFIGURATION

These are messages related to the configuration of the WIFI Radios in the adapter.

These messages are sent on initial connection and also periodically as required to reflect user changes in the configuration.

Adapter WIFI Configuration

Messages to set the Adapter Wifi Configuration.

Accepts the following message:

WIFI Configuration WifiConfiguration

Set up the WIFI Radios following this configuration.

Adapter Messages

This message causes the router to enable or disable its wifi radios, and if enabled, configure them accordingly.

  • default configuration specifies the wifi configuration for all radios within the router. Each individual radio within the router may be further configured to differ from the default by the "custom" array.

  • custom array. This array specifies the configuration differences requested for each radio within the device. Any radio which is not specified by the array obtains the default configuration. The only mandatory fields are enabled and band. If a configuration exists for a radio that does not exist, it is silently ignored. The array is optional, and may not be sent in the message if there are no per-radio customizations to apply.

  • channel setting defines the numeric channel preference for the radio. If the field is missing, or set to -1, then the channel is to be auto selected by the router. If the channel is set, the router will set the actual channel to the closest valid numeric channel for the radio. IF the router is unable to determine which channel is being requested, it simply defaults to AUTO, and does not reject the message.

  • bandwidth setting defines the radio channel bandwidth. If the setting is missing, or is set to -1, the bandwidth defaults to the widest available channel bandwidth for the radio. This is because devices should be able to downgrade their individual connection based on their capabilities and interference, and the widest channel allows for the greatest speed. If the bandwidth is specified, the router sets the bandwidth to the closest numerical bandwidth valid for the particular radio. For example, a bandwidth setting of 75 would select 80Mhz bandwidth, and not 40Mhz.

NOTE: Both channel and bandwidth are preferences and not hard configuration. The router is to attempt to make a best effort attempt to follow the preference and if it can not, default to a reasonable value, or auto select as the case dictates. Neither fields should cause the configuration to be rejected, and if the router is unable to change either setting, it will still accept the message if they are defined.

Adapter WIFI Configuration

Messages from the Adapter to confirm Wifi Configuration.

Accepts the following message:

WIFI Status WifiStatus

The current WIFI Radio status.

Adapter Messages

This message is the reply to the Wifi Configuration message. Other than the message type, all other fields should match the request.

In the case of the bandwidth and channel fields, they should be set to the actual bandwidth or channel selected for the radio, but only in the custom array. In the default config, they should be returned exactly as requested by the backend.

required
string
length <= 11 length >= 11

The current WIFI Radio status.

Const: "wifi-status"

required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The request timestamp of the configuration.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

default
required
object

Default Wifi Configuration for all radios

enabled
required
boolean

Is the WIFI Enabled or Not.

ssid
string

The name of the wifi network.

Default: "PrivacyHero"
key
string

The network password (if defined)

channel
integer
int16

The preferred channel. Default to Auto, if not present or set to -1.

bandwidth
integer
int16

The preferred channel bandwidth. Default to Max, if not present or set to -1.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

array<object>
>= 1 items

A list of customizations to apply per radio.

Items:

0
object

Custom Wifi Channel Configuration

Is the WIFI Enabled or Not.

required

Enum: "2.4Ghz" "5Ghz" "6Ghz"

string

The name of the wifi network.

Default: "PrivacyHero"

string

integer

The preferred channel. Default to Auto, if not present or set to -1.

Sub ADAPTER_DIAGNOSTICS

These are messages related to the diagnostic processes of the adapter.

Diagnostics are performed as required by the adapter, and also as a result of explicit command from the backend.

If the adapter requested a diagnostic check, the tstamp in the reply MUST match the tstamp in the request.

Adapter Diagnostics

Diagnostic reports from the Adapter.

Accepts the following message:

Log Message LogMsg

Log Message to Backend

Adapter Diagnostics

This message causes the backend to log error and general diagnostic messages from the adapter to the system logs. It can be sent anytime the adapter wishes to log a message.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 3 length >= 3

Log Message to Backend

Const: "log"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the log message was generated inside the adapter. (According to the adapters internal clock.)

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

level
required
string

The level of the log messages.

Enum: "ERROR" "WARNING" "DEBUG"
log
required
string
length >= 1

The message to be logged by the Adapter.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Pub SPEEDTEST

These are messages related to the diagnostic processes of the adapter.

Diagnostics are performed as required by the adapter, and also as a result of explicit command from the backend.

If the adapter requested a diagnostic check, the tstamp in the reply MUST match the tstamp in the request.

Speed Test

Commands to instigate speedtest checks.

Accepts the following message:

Run Speed Test RunSpeedTest

Run a Speed Test and Report the Results

Adapter Diagnostics

This message causes the adapter that receives it to perfrom ping and speedtests and return the results in a "speedtest" message.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 13 length >= 13

Run a Speed Test and Report the Results

Const: "run-speedtest"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The request timestamp of the speedtest, this tstamp must be returned in the reply with the results as the message tstamp.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

connection
required
string

The connection to test.

  • WAN is the native WAN Interface of the Adapter.
  • VPN is the through the VPN tunnel.
Enum: "WAN" "VPN"

url

OPTIONAL, if present perform speedtest against the provided servers ip address and not the one presented in configuration.

Pub DEVICE_DISCOVERY

These are messages related to the discovery of new devices or changed devices.

Device Discovery

Device Discovery messages.

Accepts the following message:

Known Device Information KnownDevices

Configures the Adapter with all devices known by the backend.

Adapter Messages

This message is sent by the Backend after initial adapter configuration upon successful connection of an adapter to the backend (after receipt of the Link Established) message. It tells the adapter all devices known by the backend. If a device is not in this list of devices that the adapter knows about, and the device is currently offline, the device is deleted. If the device is Online, a new Device Info for the device is queued to the backend to update the backends knowledge of all the connected devices. IF any of the known device data differs to the data the adapter knows about the device, a new device info message is queued to update the backends knowledge of the device.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 13 length >= 13

Configures the Adapter with all devices known by the backend.

Const: "known devices"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the device was discovered/changed.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

devices
array<object>
>= 1 items

An array of all devices known by the backend for the adapter.

Items:

0
object

Device Info

mac
required
string
Mac EUI length <= 17 length >= 1

The Devices MAC address.

ipv4
required
string
IPv4 Address length <= 15 length >= 7

The IPv4 Address assigned to this Device.

ipv6
string
IPv6 Address length <= 39 length >= 2

Optional: The IPv6 Address assigned to this Device.

user-hostname
string
length <= 255 length >= 1

The Hostname to use for the device (overrides the devices self declared hostname option 12 from the dhcp request).

online
required
boolean

The current Online state the backend believes is valid for the device. IF it is not valid, a device info message is not sent to the backend to correct it, but a "Device State Changed" message is.

dhcp
boolean

DHCP Metadata already recorded about the device. Default to false if not present.

upnp
boolean

UPNP Metadata already recorded about the device. Default to false if not present.

snmp
boolean

SNMP Metadata already recorded about the device. Default to false if not present.

bonjour
boolean

BONJOUR Metadata already recorded about the device. Default to false if not present.

smb
boolean

SMB/Netbios Metadata already recorded about the device. Default to false if not present.

hua
boolean

HTTP User Agent Metadata already recorded about the device. Default to false if not present.

Additional properties are allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

  "message": "known devices",
  "tstamp": 1592217870123,
  "id": "eyJ0aGlzIjoiaXMiLCJhbiI6ImV4YW1wbGUiLCJpZCI6ZmllbGQifQ",

    {
      "mac": "00:11:22:33:44:55",

      "online": true,
      "dhcp": true
    },
    {
      "mac": "26:C7:71:4C:97:37",
      "ipv4": "192.168.0.18",
      "ipv6": "::ffff:c0a8:12",
      "user-hostname": "OnkyoAmp",
      "online": true,
      "dhcp": true,
      "upnp": true
    }
  ]
}

Sub DEVICE_DISCOVERY

These are messages related to the discovery of new devices or changed devices.

Device Discovery

Device Discovery messages.

Accepts the following message:

Device Information DeviceInformation

Advise the Backend that the Device has been discovered or has changed.

Adapter Messages

This message is sent from the Adapter to the Backend whenever a new device is discovered, or if any of the data fields (excluding the online status) within this message about the device changes. There is no difference between a new device or updating a pre-existing device. Devices are identified by their MAC address and MAC is assumed to be unique on a single adapter.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 11 length >= 11

Advise the Backend that the Device has been discovered or has changed.

Const: "device info"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the device was discovered/changed.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

mac
required
string
Mac EUI length <= 17 length >= 1

The Devices MAC address. Assumed unique per adapter. Eg. "00:11:22:33:44:55" Also accepts "001122334455" or "00-11-22-33-44-55"

ipv4
required
string
IPv4 Address length <= 15 length >= 7

The IPv4 Address assigned to this Device. Alternatively, if the device is using a fixed IP and not one assigned by DHCP, the IP address it was discovered to be using.

ipv6
string
IPv6 Address length <= 39 length >= 2

Optional: The IPv6 Address assigned to this Device. Alternatively, if the device is using a fixed IPv6 and not one assigned by DHCP, the IP address it was discovered to be using.

online
required
boolean

Current known Online state for the device. This is the ONLY field whose change of value would not cause a new "device info" message to be sent. If a device falls offline or comes back online, the "device state" message should be sent.

meta
object

metadata discovered about the device.

dhcp
object

DHCP Data discovered about the device.

hostname
required
string
length <= 255 length >= 1

The Hostname the Device declared itself as. IF the device did not declare itself with a hostname, the adapter should synthesize a hostname for it. This hostname supplied to the backend should be the hostname only part and not include the network suffix. ie, if the device declared itself as "MyPS5" and the local lan suffix is "lan" the hostname sent should be "MyPS5". This is Option 12 from the DHCP Request.

class
string

Optional. The class of device discovered from DHCP. Can be omitted from the message if no class was provided by the device. This is option 60 from the DHCP Request.

clientid
string

Optional. The client id of device discovered from DHCP. Can be omitted from the message if no client id was provided by the device. This is option 61 from the DHCP Request.

parameters
string

Optional. The Parameter list the client requested be returned to it's dhcp request. This is option 55 from the DHCP Request.

Additional properties are allowed.

upnp
array<object>
>= 1 items

Optional. IF a upnp xml device metadata can be retrieved from a device then it is to be sent in this sub field, otherwise it is omitted. It is possible for a single physical device to report as multiple internal upnp devices. Each discovered internal upnp device is reported in this array.

Items:

0
object

UPNP Device Description

deviceType
required
string

The Device type reported by the UPNP Data of this internal device. eg: urn:schemas-upnp-org:device:InternetGatewayDevice:1

manufacturer
string

The Device manufacturer reported by the UPNP Data of this internal device. eg: Samsung

modelName
string

The Model Name reported by the UPNP Data of this internal device. eg: QN82Q80RAFXZA

friendlyName
string

The Friendly Name reported by the UPNP Data of this internal device. eg: 80" 4k QLED Flatscreen TV

serviceTypeList
array<string>
>= 1 items

The List of service types reported by the UPNP Data of this internal device. eg: ["urn:schemas-upnp-org:service:Layer3Forwarding:1"]

Items:

0
string

Individual Service Type Entry

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

object

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are allowed.

object

Pub DEVICE_CONFIGURATION

These are messages related to the configuration of known devices.

Device Configuration

Device Configuration messages.

Accepts the following message:

Change Device State ChangeDeviceState

Advise the Adapter to change the state of the devices.

Adapter Messages

This message is sent from the Backend to the adapter and instructs the adapter to make the listed state changes to the listed devices. The message can contain multiple state changes, and multiple devices. The devices listed are all triggered with the same state changes. The router will reply with a Device State Changed reply.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 19 length >= 19

Advise the Adapter to change the state of the devices.

Const: "change device state"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the backend decided the state should change. To be returned in the paired reply.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

devices
required
array<string>
>= 1 items

An array of Device MAC addresses the state changes are to be applied to. All devices listed are to have the same state change made as listed in this message. Only after all devices states have been changed does the adapter send the paired reply.

Items:

0
string
Mac EUI length <= 17 length >= 1

The Devices MAC address. Assumed unique per adapter. Eg. "00:11:22:33:44:55" Also accepts "001122334455" or "00-11-22-33-44-55"

Additional items are allowed.

states
required
array<object>
>= 1 items

The array of services and states to change. If the service already has the requested state on the device no change is made but the reply includes this state. If the service is not present in the states array, its state is not changed, and its current state is NOT returned to the paired reply.

Items:

0
object

Service State

service
required
string

The service/filter on the device which we wish to change the state of.

  • vpn - The Device will route through the VPN when True (if VPN is enabled)
  • ad-blocking - Ad Blocking is Enabled on the device when True.
  • device-protection - Device Protection is Enabled on the device when True.
  • internet-pause - Internet is paused for the device when True.
  • youtube-restricted - Youtube returns restricted search results when True.
  • safesearch - Search Engines return "safe" results when True.
  • adultcontent - Adult Content is "blocked" when True.

Note: internet-pause also has a timed mode. The boolean option in this message terminates any timed-pause current on the device and sets the state accordingly.

Enum: "vpn" "ad-blocking" "device-protection" "internet-pause" "youtube-restricted" "safesearch" "adultcontent" "online"
state
required
boolean
  • true - The service/filter is enabled.
  • false - The service/filter is disabled.
timeout
integer
epoch timestamp [seconds] (int64)

OPTIONAL, specifies a duration for the state to be set before it changes to the opposite state. It is specified as the number of seconds follwing the receipt and processing of this message. IF this message is present, the reply will have the "finishes" field set, which is the time NOW + this timeout, NOW is determined by the internal clock of the adapter.

NOTE: Currently this field will ONLY be sent if required for the internet-pause state.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Device Messages

Examples

ChangeDeviceState
Payload 
{
  "message": "change device state",
  "tstamp": 1592217870123,
  "id": "eyJ0aGlzIjoiaXMiLCJhbiI6ImV4YW1wbGUiLCJpZCI6ZmllbGQifQ",
  "devices": [
    "53:CB:12:79:E5:F6",
    "DD:0F:91:FE:9E:00",
    "54:A4:33:F5:D8:A4"
  ],
  "states": [
    {
      "service": "ad-blocking",
      "state": false
    },
    {
      "service": "internet-pause",
      "state": false
    },
    {
      "service": "safe-search",
      "state": true
    }
  ]
}
This example has been generated automatically.

Sub DEVICE_CONFIGURATION

These are messages related to the configuration of known devices.

Device Configuration

Device Configuration messages.

Accepts the following message:

Device State Changed DeviceStateChanged

Advise the Adapter to change the state of the devices.

Adapter Messages

This message is sent from the Adapter to the Backend and either confirms the adapters request to set state from the Change Device State message, OR advises that the state changed asynchronously without being requested by the backend.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 20 length >= 20

Advise the Adapter to change the state of the devices.

Const: "device state changed"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

IF this is a reply to the backend setting the device state, this must equal the tstamp in the original request. IF this is an advice that a state changed asynchronously, this is the time the adapter changed/detected the state.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

devices
required
array<string>
>= 1 items

An array of Device MAC addresses the state changes were applied to. All devices listed had the same state change made as listed in this message.

Items:

0
string
Mac EUI length <= 17 length >= 1

The Devices MAC address. Assumed unique per adapter. Eg. "00:11:22:33:44:55" Also accepts "001122334455" or "00-11-22-33-44-55"

Additional items are allowed.

states
required
array<object>
>= 1 items

The array of services and states that change. If this is a reply to the Change Device State command from the backend, then it lists the same states that were requested by the backend. If asynchronous state changes occur, the actual changes that ocurred are listed only.

Items:

0
object

Service State

service
required
string

The service/filter on the device which changed state.

  • vpn - The Device will route through the VPN when True (if VPN is enabled)
  • ad-blocking - Ad Blocking is Enabled on the device when True.
  • device-protection - Device Protection is Enabled on the device when True.
  • internet-pause - Internet is paused for the device when True.
  • youtube-restricted - Youtube returns restricted search results when True.
  • safesearch - Search Engines return "safe" results when True.
  • adultcontent - Adult Content is "blocked" when True.
  • online - If the device is online or not. Only an asynchronous state change.

Note: internet-pause also has a timed mode. The boolean option in this message terminates any timed-pause current on the device and sets the state accordingly. online is only an asynchronous state change. it is only ever sent as a result of the adapter detecting a device coming online or falling offline.

Enum: "vpn" "ad-blocking" "device-protection" "internet-pause" "youtube-restricted" "safesearch" "adultcontent" "online"
state
required
boolean
  • true - The service/filter is enabled.
  • false - The service/filter is disabled.
finishes
integer
epoch timestamp [seconds] (int64)

OPTIONAL, and ONLY INCLUDED when a timeout is supplied for the state, this field in the reply specifies when the timed operation will complete. It is the Unix Epoch Date/Time as seconds since midnight 1970 UTC.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

    },

    },

      "service": "safe-search",
      "state": true
    }
  ]
}

Pub DEVICE_BEDTIME_CFG

These are messages related to the configuration of device bedtime schedules.

Device Bedtime Configuration

Device Bedtime Configuration messages.

Accepts one of the following messages:

#1 Set Device Bedtime SetBedtime

Advise the Adapter to set the bedtime schedule for the listed devices.

Adapter Messages

This message is sent from the Backend to the adapter and instructs the adapter to set the listed bedtime schedule for the listed devices. The devices listed are all set to the same bedtime schedule. The Adapter will receive multiple "set bedtime" messages to set the schedules of all known devices. If the Adapter knows a device, but has not received a bedtime schedule for it, it must assume there is no bedtime schedule that applies to it. The full set of bedtime schedules are sent during initial configuration, in response to the backend receiving the Link Established message. It is also sent as required to reflect configuration changes as they occur. Once set, the backend replies with the Bedtime Set message, with the tstamp and id (if present) matching those same fields in this request.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 11 length >= 11

Advise the Adapter to set the bedtime schedule for the listed devices.

Const: "set bedtime"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the backend decided to set the bedtime schedule. To be returned in the paired reply.

id
required
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

devices
required
array<string>
>= 1 items

An array of Device MAC addresses the bedtime schedule applies to. All devices listed are to have the same bedtime schedule applied to them. Only after all listed devices have the bedtime schedule applied does the adapter send the paired reply.

Items:

0
string
Mac EUI length <= 17 length >= 1

The Devices MAC address. Assumed unique per adapter. Eg. "00:11:22:33:44:55" Also accepts "001122334455" or "00-11-22-33-44-55"

Additional items are allowed.

schedule
required
array<object>
>= 7 items <= 7 items

This is an array for a rotating weeks worth of bedtime schedules. The first element is Monday, the second Tuesday, Wednesday and so on till Sunday. There will ALWAYS be 7 days present if a schedule is set.

IF no schedule is to be set for the specified devices, the schedule field will be present, and will be set to null. This means that no schedule is to apply to the listed devices.

IF any single day does not have a bed time, but other days do, then both the "start" and "end" will be set to 0 (zero).

Items:

0
object

Bedtime Schedule

start
required
integer
int16

This is the time bedtime starts on the specificed day.

This time is minutes since midnight of the specified day.

IF bedtime starts after the subsequent midnight of the specified day, then this time will be greater than 1,440.

Assuming the specified day is Monday. Example Start Times:

  • 600 = 10am Monday Morning.
  • 1,260 = 9pm Monday Night.
  • 1,350 = 10:30pm Monday Night.
  • 1,530 = 1:30am Tuesday Morning.
end
required
integer
int16

This is the time bedtime ends on the specificed day.

This time is minutes since midnight of the specified day.

Bedtime typically always ends after the subsequent midnight of the specified day, so typically this time will be greater than 1,440.

start is always < end. If it is not the schedule is in error and should be rejected.

Assuming the specified day is Monday. Example End Times:

  • 1,800 = 6am Tuesday Morning.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

#2 Delay Bedtime DelayBedtime

Advise the Router to delay the current or next bedtime start.

Adapter Messages

This message causes the adapter to delay the bedtime for the listed devices by the specified number of minutes. It is a one-shot delay and once expired is not repeated.

IF bedtime has not yet commenced for the day, the delay applies to the bedtime which is next to occur. The delay then causes the start to delay by the specified number of minutes.

IF the bedtime has started but not yet finished, the delay applies to the currently active bedtime, and will delay it from its start time by the specified number of minutes. So, for example, if started at 10pm and at 10:15pm a delay of 45 minutes was received, the devices internet would unpause and would re-pause at 10:45. This message is responded to with the Bedtime Delayed message from the router.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 13 length >= 13

Advise the Router to delay the current or next bedtime start.

Const: "delay bedtime"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the backend decided to set the bedtime delay. To be returned in the paired reply.

id
required
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

devices
required
array<string>
>= 1 items

An array of Device MAC addresses the bedtime delay applies to. All devices listed are to have the same bedtime delay applied to them. Only after all listed devices have the bedtime delay applied does the adapter send the paired reply.

Items:

0
string
Mac EUI length <= 17 length >= 1

The Devices MAC address. Assumed unique per adapter. Eg. "00:11:22:33:44:55" Also accepts "001122334455" or "00-11-22-33-44-55"

Additional items are allowed.

delay
required
integer
int16

The number of minutes we are to delay bedtime for the listed devices for. A delay of zero terminates any currently running delay. Delay time is absolute, from the start of the next/current bedtime. A subsequent delay is NOT an additional delay, it replaces the current delay.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Sub DATA_USAGE

These are messages related to the periodic reporting of data usage.

Data Usage

Data Usage messages.

Accepts the following message:

Data Usage DataUsage

Advise the Backend of the data usage for the hour.

Adapter Messages Device Messages

This message is sent from the Adapter to the Backend every hour and is synchronized to the top of each hour. It reports the data usage for both the Adapter as a whole, and each ACTIVE device within that hour.

In order to prevent spikes of data hitting the backend at the end of every hour, this message should be delayed to be sent for a random interval up to 10 minutes, after the end of each hour. However, the tstamp field should reflect the hour that is being reported, and NOT the time the message was actually sent.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 10 length >= 10

Advise the Backend of the data usage for the hour.

Const: "data usage"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time of the Adapter/Device Data Usage Report, this should be synchronized to the top of each hour.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

tx
required
integer
int64

This is the total number of bytes sent by the Adapter to the internet in the hour.

rx
required
integer
int64

This is the total number of bytes received by the Adapter from the internet in the hour.

devices
array<object>
>= 1 items

The list of all devices which were active during the hour and transmitted or received data from the internet. Devices which were online, but only transmitted locally are NOT listed. If there were no active devices, this field is omitted.

Items:

0
object

The list of all devices which were active during the hour and transmitted or received data from the internet. Devices which were online, but only transmitted locally are NOT listed. If there were no active devices, this field is omitted.

mac
required
string
Mac EUI length <= 17 length >= 1

The mac address of the active device being reported.

tx
required
integer
int64

This is the total number of bytes sent by the Device to the internet in the hour. Data which was sent locally is not included, only data routed out to the public internet is included.

rx
required
integer
int64

This is the total number of bytes received by the Device from the internet in the hour. Data which was received locally is not included, only data routed in from the public internet to the device is included.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

Messages

#1 Base Message BaseMsg

Standard Message Base Format

Message Formats

All Privacy Hero 2 system messages have the following standard form.

Payload
object
message
required
string

This is the name of the message. The operation that is to be performed and the further fields contained within the message can be identified based solely on this message type string.

tstamp
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

Every adapter/backend generated message contains a unique tstamp field. This field defines both the time of a particular event having ocurred, and the pairing of messages in the case of events which are triggered as a result of commands from the backend.

An Adapter will always return the tstamp of any message it is replying to. IF the Adapter is generating an event asynchronously and not as a result of a direct comment, the tstamp contains the time of the event as generated by the adapter.

The Field is an integer and is the number of milliseconds since midnight 1970, UTC. Otherwise known as the Unix Epoch.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

Additional properties are allowed.

#2 Multi Message MultiMsg

Multiple Message Packet

Message Formats

All Privacy Hero 2 system messages may be bundled into a single multi-message. The multi message is a standard message, which hold an array of individual messages. The individual messages when received will be treated as if they were received sequentially and independently in the order they are listed.

The purpose of a Multi-Message is to cluster message processing for efficiency.

Notes regarding adapter bundling implementation.

The Backend is charged in 100ms units of execution. It also takes time for the backend to startup and begin processing. Therefore, it is preferable, unless the message is urgent, that all messages are bundled in the adapter in a minimum of 200ms blocks. If an urgent message must be sent, it should be added to the current bundle and the entire bundle be sent immediately.

The maximum single multi-message size must not exceed 32KB. If adding a message to the bundle would cause the message size to exceed 32KB, the bundle should be sent and the message which would have exceeded the size is added to the next bundle. IF a message is defined which does exceed 32KB, it should not be bundled, but MUST be sent as a discreet message. In this case, the maximum message size must never exceed 128KB.

The multi-message is guaranteed NOT to have an id field, but the messages contained within it, may have id fields and they should be processed accordingly.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 5 length >= 5

Multiple Message Packet.

Const: "multi"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The time the message was generated, unrelated to the bundled messages timestamps.

msgs
required
array<object>
>= 1 items <= 32 items

An array of complete and individual messages as defined elsewhere in this specification.

Items:

0
object
message
required
string

This is the name of the message. The operation that is to be performed and the further fields contained within the message can be identified based solely on this message type string.

tstamp
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

Every adapter/backend generated message contains a unique tstamp field. This field defines both the time of a particular event having ocurred, and the pairing of messages in the case of events which are triggered as a result of commands from the backend.

An Adapter will always return the tstamp of any message it is replying to. IF the Adapter is generating an event asynchronously and not as a result of a direct comment, the tstamp contains the time of the event as generated by the adapter.

The Field is an integer and is the number of milliseconds since midnight 1970, UTC. Otherwise known as the Unix Epoch.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

Additional properties are allowed.

Additional items are allowed.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

#3 AWS Internal Server Error AWSInternalServerError

AWS Internal Server Error

AWS Errors

This message is generated directly by AWS, and does not contain a tstamp.

This messages indicates something fatal has ocurred in the server. Upon receipt, the adapter should record the fact it ocurred, and try and reconnect to the backend, if a successful reconnection occurs, the adapter should log the internal server error to the backend, and then continue.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 21 length >= 21

An internal server error, AWS Generated

Const: "Internal server error"
connectionId
required
string

The AWS Websocket Connection ID.

requestId
required
string

The ID of the request which caused the error.

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

AWS Server Error

AWS Errors

This message is generated directly by AWS, and does not contain a tstamp.

This messages indicates something fatal has ocurred in the server. Upon receipt, the adapter should record the fact it ocurred, and try and reconnect to the backend, if a successful reconnection occurs, the adapter should log the internal server error to the backend, and then continue.

Payload

required
string
length <= 5 length >= 5

Const: "Error"

#5 Initial Configuration InitialConfig

Initial Highest Level Configuration

Adapter Messages

This message contains the highest level configuration and is sent by the backend after a link is established, and the backend receives the Link Established message from the Adapter.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 11 length >= 11

Initial Highest Level Configuration

Const: "initial cfg"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The tstamp in this message is the same tstamp sent in the Link Established message from the adapter which triggered it to be sent.

version
required
string
bas64-url-sha256 length <= 43 length >= 43

The version of the latest firmaware suitable for the adapter. This version should match the version installed in the adapter before it continues. If it does noe, the adapter should retrieve the new version from the url in this message, program that and restart the connection.

firmware
required
string
url

The firmware url. This is the location where the latest firmware may be downloaded. If the adapter detects that a firmware update is required it downloads the firmware from this URL. If the firmware can not be downloaded or the image downloaded does not match the version hash, then the firmware in the adapter must not be changed, and an error should be logged to the backend.

loglevel
required
string

The Minimum level of messages which should be logged to the backend.

Enum: "NONE" "ERROR" "WARNING" "DEBUG"

Additional properties are NOT allowed.

#8 Link Established LinkEstablished

Advise the Backend that the Adapter has connected to a new websocket

Adapter Messages

This message is sent from the Adapter to the Backend as the very first message it sends AFTER establishing any websocket connection to the backend. It allows the backend to perform link connection housekeeping for the adapter, which is necessary for proper operation.

Upon receipt, the Backend will queue the initial configuration for the router in the following order:

  1. Initial Configuration
  2. Unsubscribed Whitelist
  3. Block List Cfg (1 message for each blocklist category)
  4. Adapter Services
  5. WIFI Configuration
  6. VPN Server Connect
  7. Streaming Auth
  8. Streaming Cfg
  9. Known Devices
  10. Change Device State (As many as required to configure all devices)
  11. Set Bedtime (1 message each for as many bedtime schedules exist.)

#10 Adapter Services AdapterServices

Configure Adapter Level services on the Adapter.

Adapter Messages

This message causes the adapter that receives it to turn on/off the adapter wide services specified. If any service is not specified, its state is not changed.

IF the message contains multiple states, they may be replied to either individually or as a group. In particular, "VPN" may take a long time to start. "VPN" will not be replied to until the "VPN" has fully started or has failed.

See the "vpn_status_update" message which allows progressive and detailed vpn startup/shutdown state to be reported to the Backend asynchronously.

Regardless of the requested state, the reply for "VPN" always reflects the state which was achieved. ie, if the VPN state in teh request was true, but the VPN failed to start, the reply must specify the actual state as false. If other states may also fail to configure, they too must be replied with their actual state, and not the requested state.

#11 Adapter Services State AdapterServicesState

If the configuration command contained multiple services, the reply may also contain multiple services, or services may be responded to in a group or individual, depending on how long the service takes to start on the adapter and the adapters implementation. VPN status updates are not reported using this message. See the VPN Connection Status message for details.

IF a service state can change without command from the backend, this message is sent unsolicited with the changed state for the service. in that case, the tstamp MUST be set to the tstamp of the time the state changed on the adapter, and there must be no ID field.

#14 VPN Server Connect VPNConnect

Connect to a listed VPN Server.

Adapter Messages

This message causes the router to attempt to connect to one of the listed VPN servers.

If there are untested servers in the list (servers without either the "speed" or "latency" fields in their configuration), the router will test them, and send the result back to the backend. After testing is completed, the router will sort them, in order of fatest/lowest latency and then attempt to connect in that order.

If there are no servers to be tested, then they are attempted to be connected in the order presented.

IF the router has already established a VPN connection, AND the VPN server connected is present in the list (regardless of whether it has test data or not), then no reconnection will occur and it will not disconnect or attempt to reconnect as a result of receiving this message. It will simply reply with the VPN Connection Status Message indicating the current server is connected.

However, if the current VPN server connected IS NOT in the list, then the connection will be dropped and the list will be processed as if there was no connection to begin with.

IF the server list is empty, and the VPN is connected, the Router will immediately drop the connection and report the connection is down using the VPN Connection Status message.

This message is sent when a client requests the VPN connection be established, OR the Router has requested a VPN Server Reconnect.

Because the router can ONLY rely on the credentials it was presented at the time the vpn-connect message was received, if for any reason the VPN tunnel disconnects, the router can try to immediately reconnect to the same tunnel with the same credentials. If that fails, it can not use the credentials presented for any other tunnel as they may have expired or have been assigned to a different client. In that case, the router can send a VPN Server Reconnect message to the backend to be provided with a fresh list of VPN servers and credentials with wish to re-establish VPN connection. The backend will then reply with this VPN Server Connect message.

Payload
object
message
required
string
length <= 11 length >= 11

Connect to a listed VPN Server.

Const: "vpn-connect"
tstamp
required
integer
epoch timestamp [milliseconds] (int64)

The request timestamp of the configuration.

id
string
length <= 256 length >= 1

Optional, ID Field. The Adapter does not do any processing or verification of the ID field, if it is set, it must be returned verbatim in the paired reply.

servers
required
array<object>
>= 1 items

The message will contain a list of viable pre-selected servers.

The highest priority entires (and therefore the first listed) will be those servers which require testing, in order of test priority. There may be no servers of this type listed if there are no servers that REQUIRE testing.

Following this will be a list of servers in priority order. When connecting to the VPN, the router is to use this list and try to connect in the order presented. IF the router is unable to establish a connection after trying all servers, it gives up attempting to connect.

Items:

0
object

The configuration for an individual VPN server.

The vpn_id is to be used to report about status and speedtest results for the configured vpn tunnel.

speed is the average speedtest TX result from the last months worth vpn speedtests on this server. IF there is no speed field, the router is to create the speed value by connecting the tunnel and performing the speedtest. The resulting TX speed in bytes per second of this one test becomes the speed for the purpose of selecting the fastest VPN Server. Speed is selected as the TX value because most consumer internet connections are asynchronous, but have higher raw TX speed than RX, that means that any speedtest is more likely to max out RX than TX.

latency is the average latency to the speedtest server from the last months worth of speedtest results on the server. IF there is a missing latency result (ie, the speedtest reported -1) then the latency value for the purpose of averaging is taken to be 1000ms which will force the latency to dis-favor links with unreliable connections. The average is rounded to the nearest whole millisecond.

speed and latency will either both be present, or neither present. If neither is present, the VPN tunnel is to be started and tested.

The array will be pre-sorted in order from backend identified fastest server to slowest. However, when the router must perform a speedtest to determine the vpn speed, it must resort. The sorting algorithm works like this:

Place all servers in an unsorted list of servers.
Create a sorted list of servers which initally is empty.

Of the servers in the list of unsorted servers, get the maximum speed
value.
Of the servers in the unsorted list whose speed is within 10% of the
fastest speed in the list, remove the server with the lowest latency value
and add it to the end of the list of sorted vpn servers.
Repeat this selection process until there are no more servers in the
unsorted server list.

This algorithm will create a list of servers which trend from fastest/lowest latency down to slowest/highest latency.

vpn_id
required
string

Unique VPN ID

speed
integer
int64

Current rated bandwidth for the tunnel in bytes per second.

latency
integer
int64

Current rated latency for the tunnel in milliseconds.

config
oneOf
0
object

The configuration for an individual wireguard server.

required
string
length <= 9 length >= 9

Const: "wireguard"

required

#16 VPN Connection Status VPNStatus

Report VPN Connection Status.

Adapter Messages

This message advises the current VPN status to the backend.

During VPN connection, multiple status messages should be sent tracking the major phases of VPN connection initiation, and also, reconnections on a failed link and link disconnection. VPN Connection/Disconnection is triggered by the receipt of a VPN Server Connect message.

required

The current status of the VPN process.

  • test-connecting = Connecting to a VPN server to test.
  • testing = Test connection to VPN succeeded and test started. Test results will be sent in Speedtest Result.
  • test-failed = Either the connection couldn't be established to test, or the test has failed to execute.
  • connecting = Connecting the VPN tunnel for general use.
  • connected = The connection to the VPN is established and routing is operational.
  • failed = The vpn server failed to connect or the link broke. After this call the router may no longer use the credentials presented in VPN Server Connect for the server.
  • reconnecting = The VPN server was running and failed, trying to reconnect. This status is sent instead of the connecting status when a vpn link was established, but dropped and we are attempting to re-establish the connection.
  • disconnected = The last possible server was tested and failed, giving up trying to enable VPN. server should not be present, as no server is being accessed in this state.

#18 WIFI Configuration WifiConfiguration

Set up the WIFI Radios following this configuration.

Adapter Messages

This message causes the router to enable or disable its wifi radios, and if enabled, configure them accordingly.

  • default configuration specifies the wifi configuration for all radios within the router. Each individual radio within the router may be further configured to differ from the default by the "custom" array.

  • custom array. This array specifies the configuration differences requested for each radio within the device. Any radio which is not specified by the array obtains the default configuration. The only mandatory fields are enabled and band. If a configuration exists for a radio that does not exist, it is silently ignored. The array is optional, and may not be sent in the message if there are no per-radio customizations to apply.

  • channel setting defines the numeric channel preference for the radio. If the field is missing, or set to -1, then the channel is to be auto selected by the router. If the channel is set, the router will set the actual channel to the closest valid numeric channel for the radio. IF the router is unable to determine which channel is being requested, it simply defaults to AUTO, and does not reject the message.

  • bandwidth setting defines the radio channel bandwidth. If the setting is missing, or is set to -1, the bandwidth defaults to the widest available channel bandwidth for the radio. This is because devices should be able to downgrade their individual connection based on their capabilities and interference, and the widest channel allows for the greatest speed. If the bandwidth is specified, the router sets the bandwidth to the closest numerical bandwidth valid for the particular radio. For example, a bandwidth setting of 75 would select 80Mhz bandwidth, and not 40Mhz.

NOTE: Both channel and bandwidth are preferences and not hard configuration. The router is to attempt to make a best effort attempt to follow the preference and if it can not, default to a reasonable value, or auto select as the case dictates. Neither fields should cause the configuration to be rejected, and if the router is unable to change either setting, it will still accept the message if they are defined.
